articles.title: A strange star near a black hole is defying expectations
articles.summary: Astronomers have decoded the hidden past of a distant red giant star by listening to tiny vibrations in its light, revealing clues of a dramatic cosmic history. The star, which quietly orbits a dormant black hole, appears to be spinning far faster than it should—and its internal “starquakes” suggest it may have once collided and merged with another star. Even more puzzling, its chemical makeup makes it look ancient, while its internal structure reveals it’s relatively young.
articles.content:
Astronomers at the University of Hawaiʻi Institute for Astronomy (IfA) have pieced together the dramatic history of a distant red giant by studying subtle changes in its light. Tiny fluctuations in brightness reveal that the star may have collided and merged with another star long ago, a violent event that likely left it spinning much faster than normal. Today, this unusual star circles a quiet black hole in a system known as Gaia BH2.

Using observations from NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS), the team detected faint vibrations known as "starquakes" moving through the red giant, which is the companion to the black hole. Gaia BH2 itself was first identified in 2023 by the European Space Agency's Gaia mission. Much like earthquakes help scientists explore Earth's interior, these stellar tremors allowed astronomers to probe deep inside the star and precisely measure properties of its core. The results of this work were recently published in Astronomical Journal.

"Just like seismologists use earthquakes to study Earth's interior, we can use stellar oscillations to understand what's happening inside distant stars," said IfA research scientist Daniel Hey, lead author of the study. "These vibrations told us something unexpected about this star's history."

A Star That Appears Older Than It Is

One of the most surprising findings came from the star's chemical composition. The red giant is described as "alpha-rich," meaning it contains large amounts of heavy elements that are typically found in very old stars. Based on its chemistry alone, the star should be ancient.

However, analysis of its internal vibrations told a different story. The star is actually about 5 billion years old, far younger than its chemical makeup would suggest. That mismatch presents a puzzle for astronomers trying to understand how the star formed.

"Young, alpha-rich stars are quite rare and puzzling," explained Hey. "The combination of youth and ancient chemistry suggests this star didn't evolve in isolation. It likely acquired extra mass from a companion, either through a merger or by absorbing material when the black hole formed."

Spinning Faster Than Expected

Additional clues came from long-term monitoring with ground-based telescopes. These observations show the star completes one full rotation every 398 days, which is unusually fast for a red giant of its age that evolved alone.

"If this rotation is real, it can't be explained by the star's birth spin alone," said co-author Joel Ong, a NASA Hubble Fellow at IfA. "The star must have been spun up through tidal interactions with its companion, which further supports the idea that this system has a complex history."

Comparing Quiet Black Hole Systems

The researchers also studied Gaia BH3, another black hole system with an even stranger companion star. Existing models predicted that this star should display strong oscillations, yet none were observed. This unexpected result suggests that current theories about stars with extremely low metal content may need to be revised.

Both Gaia BH2 and Gaia BH3 belong to a class of dormant black hole systems. These black holes are not actively pulling in material from their companion stars, which means they do not emit X-rays. Instead, astronomers discovered them by carefully tracking the motion of nearby stars. These findings are changing how scientists search for and study black holes within the Milky Way.

What Comes Next

Future observations from TESS will allow astronomers to study Gaia BH2's stellar vibrations in even greater detail. With more data, the team hopes to confirm whether the red giant truly formed through a past stellar merger and to better understand how these quiet black hole pairs develop over time.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about a star's unusual history and behavior near a dormant black hole, using innovative methods like stellar vibrations to probe its interior. This advances understanding of stellar evolution and black hole systems, with broad implications for astrophysics and space science, benefiting the general public's knowledge of the universe.

Ce trou noir n’aspire pas de matière et ne brille pas, ce qui le rend difficile à détecter. En observant de petites variations dans la lumière de l’étoile, les astronomes voulaient en savoir plus sur son passé.

Cela permettra de confirmer si l’étoile a vraiment fusionné avec une autre et d’améliorer la connaissance de l’évolution des paires trou noir silencieux-étoile.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – En écoutant les séismes stellaires, les astronomes ont révélé le passé surprenant d’une géante rouge près d’un trou noir silencieux, apportant de nouvelles connaissances sur les systèmes d’étoiles et de trous noirs.

articles.title: Studying Physics in Microgravity
articles.summary: In this Oct. 20, 2025, photo, tiny ball bearings surround a larger central bearing during the Fluid Particles experiment, conducted inside the Microgravity Science Glovebox (MSG) aboard the International Space Station’s Destiny laboratory module. A bulk container installed in the MSG, filled with viscous fluid and embedded particles, is subjected to oscillating frequencies to observe […]
articles.content:
NASA/Zena Cardman

In this Oct. 20, 2025, photo, tiny ball bearings surround a larger central bearing during the Fluid Particles experiment, conducted inside the Microgravity Science Glovebox (MSG) aboard the International Space Station’s Destiny laboratory module. A bulk container installed in the MSG, filled with viscous fluid and embedded particles, is subjected to oscillating frequencies to observe how the particles cluster and form larger structures in microgravity. Insights from this research may advance fire suppression, lunar dust mitigation, and plant growth in space. On Earth, the findings could inform our understanding of pollen dispersion, algae blooms, plastic pollution, and sea salt transport during storms.

In addition to uncovering potential benefits on Earth, research done aboard the space station helps inform long-duration missions like Artemis and future human expeditions to Mars.

Image credit: NASA/Zena Cardman
articles.reasoning: The article describes a scientific experiment aboard the International Space Station that has significant potential benefits both for future space exploration and for understanding important environmental and physical processes on Earth. The research has broad implications for fire suppression, lunar dust mitigation, plant growth in space, and environmental phenomena on Earth, indicating meaningful real-world impact and substance.
articles.personality_title: Space experiment reveals new clues about particles and fluids in microgravity
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists aboard the International Space Station (ISS) are studying how tiny particles behave in fluids when there is very little gravity. This research is done inside a special lab area called the Microgravity Science Glovebox (MSG), located in the station’s Destiny module.

**What happened** – On October 20, 2025, researchers conducted the Fluid Particles experiment. They placed a container filled with thick liquid and small particles inside the MSG. By shaking the container at different speeds, they watched how the particles grouped together and formed larger clumps in the low-gravity environment.

**Impact** – Understanding how particles move and cluster in space helps solve problems for astronauts, like reducing dust on the Moon and improving fire safety. It also helps plants grow better during long space trips. On Earth, this research can explain natural events such as how pollen spreads, why algae blooms happen, how plastic pollution moves in water, and how sea salt travels during storms.

**What's next step** – Scientists will use the experiment’s results to design better tools and methods for future space missions, like NASA’s Artemis program to the Moon and planned trips to Mars. They will also explore how these findings can improve environmental protection and safety back on Earth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A space station experiment studying particles in fluids is helping improve space travel and deepen our understanding of important Earth processes.

articles.title: Was 2025 the year we found signs of past life on Mars?
articles.summary: Tantalising signs of past microbial life showed up on Mars this year, but to truly know whether they contain the answer to the biggest question in the universe, we will need to bring samples back to Earth
articles.content:
Tantalising signs of past microbial life showed up on Mars this year, but to truly know whether they contain the answer to the biggest question in the universe, we will need to bring samples back to Earth

NASA’s Perseverance rover, the first mission to collect and cache Martian rock and regolith NASA/JPL-Caltech

On Mars, it’s the little things that hint at past life. In 2025, tiny details in rocks across the Martian surface have revealed some of the most exciting clues yet that there may once have been microbial life there.

These come from analysis of samples collected by NASA’s Perseverance rover, which began to provide evidence of life last year: Perseverance came across rocks with tiny splotches, each just millimetres wide with a ring of dark material around it. These splotches, dubbed “leopard spots”, are similar to features we see on Earth associated with fossils of microbes.

This year, Joel Hurowitz at Stony Brook University in New York state and his colleagues did more detailed analyses on the leopard spots, finding forms of iron and sulphur that often come from chemical reactions involving microbes. “I find it much more promising [an indication of life] than anything I’ve seen in the last 20 years,” says Hanna Sizemore at the Planetary Science Institute in Arizona.

Past findings that hinted at life on Mars included unexpected variation in the planet’s methane levels, along with fossil-like structures in Martian meteorites. “I am more enthusiastic about these findings than any of those,” says Sizemore. “That was all at the wrong physical scale.” The leopard spots, on the other hand, are just about the right size to be caused by microbes, she says.

The same is true for the other potential biosignatures Perseverance found this year: tiny greenish nodules of minerals that, on Earth, tend to be linked with microbial life. “It was always obvious that life there isn’t obvious. It’s not herds of wildebeests sweeping majestically across the plain,” says Andrew Steele at Carnegie Science in Washington DC, who was part of the team that developed the science goals for Perseverance. “Whatever these signs are, they’re going to be subtle, and we need the best instruments available to us to look for them.”

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

The Perseverance rover captured an image of a rock with distinctive “leopard spots” NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS

Perseverance does have a sophisticated suite of scientific instruments, but if we want to definitively determine whether these rocks have signs of past life, we have to bring the samples back to Earth to be examined in laboratories here. That was always the plan: Perseverance would cache samples, and a future mission would pick them up and bring them back.

“These samples represent the best chance that we have of a next step in the analysis of whether there is [or has been] life on Mars – we just have to bring them back,” says Steele.

Unfortunately, that prospect is looking less and less likely. The Mars Sample Return project is marked for cancellation in the Trump administration’s proposed NASA budget for 2026; if that budget is approved, there will be no plan to pick up the samples that Perseverance has so carefully collected.

Indeed, it is possible that we have found signs of life on Mars and might never know it. “We keep making so much progress, but our big picture of Martian habitability keeps not moving,” says Sizemore. “We’re right on the edge – we cannot dismiss it and we cannot prove it. It’s only missions on the ground that will change that.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough with the discovery of tantalizing signs of past microbial life on Mars, based on detailed analysis of samples collected by NASA's Perseverance rover. This discovery has broad significance for humanity's understanding of life beyond Earth and the universe. Although the future sample return mission faces funding challenges, the current findings represent a meaningful and inspiring advancement in space exploration and astrobiology.
articles.personality_title: New clues of past life found on Mars by NASA rover
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long wondered if life ever existed on Mars. NASA’s Perseverance rover, which landed on Mars in 2021, was sent to collect rock and soil samples to help answer this question.

**What happened** – In 2025, researchers studied tiny spots on Martian rocks, called "leopard spots," found by Perseverance. These spots contain iron and sulfur patterns that on Earth often form because of microbes. Other small mineral nodules linked to life were also found. Experts say these signs are the strongest evidence yet of possible past microbial life on Mars.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it shows Mars had conditions that might have supported tiny living things long ago. The clues are subtle and small, but they match what scientists expect if microbes once lived there. This moves the search for life beyond Earth forward by giving clear targets for study.

**What's next step** – To be sure if life really existed, the rock samples need to be brought back to Earth for more detailed tests. Perseverance saved these samples, but the mission to return them is uncertain because of possible budget cuts. Without bringing samples back, we may never fully know if life was on Mars.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s rover found promising signs of past microbial life on Mars, but bringing samples home is key to confirming this discovery.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouveaux indices de vie passée découverts sur Mars par le rover de la NASA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques se demandent depuis longtemps si la vie a existé un jour sur Mars. Le rover Perseverance de la NASA, arrivé sur Mars en 2021, a été envoyé pour collecter des échantillons de roches et de sol afin de répondre à cette question.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2025, des chercheurs ont étudié de petites taches sur des roches martiennes, appelées « taches léopard », découvertes par Perseverance. Ces taches contiennent des motifs de fer et de soufre qui, sur Terre, se forment souvent à cause de microbes. D’autres petits nodules minéraux liés à la vie ont aussi été trouvés. Les experts disent que ce sont les preuves les plus fortes à ce jour d’une vie microbienne passée possible sur Mars.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que Mars avait des conditions pouvant avoir accueilli de petits êtres vivants il y a longtemps. Les indices sont subtils et petits, mais ils correspondent à ce que les scientifiques attendent si des microbes y ont vécu. Cela fait avancer la recherche de vie au-delà de la Terre en donnant des cibles claires pour l’étude.

**Prochaine étape** – Pour être sûr que la vie a vraiment existé, il faut ramener les échantillons sur Terre pour des analyses plus détaillées. Perseverance a conservé ces échantillons, mais la mission de retour est incertaine à cause de possibles réductions budgétaires. Sans ramener les échantillons, nous ne saurons peut-être jamais si la vie était sur Mars.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le rover de la NASA a trouvé des signes prometteurs de vie microbienne passée sur Mars, mais ramener les échantillons est essentiel pour confirmer cette découverte.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas pistas de vida pasada encontradas en Marte por el rover de la NASA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han preguntado durante mucho tiempo si alguna vez hubo vida en Marte. El rover Perseverance de la NASA, que aterrizó en Marte en 2021, fue enviado para recoger muestras de rocas y suelo para ayudar a responder esta pregunta.

**Qué pasó** – En 2025, los investigadores estudiaron pequeñas manchas en rocas marcianas, llamadas "manchas de leopardo", encontradas por Perseverance. Estas manchas contienen patrones de hierro y azufre que en la Tierra a menudo se forman por microbios. También se encontraron otros pequeños nódulos minerales relacionados con la vida. Los expertos dicen que estas son las pruebas más fuertes hasta ahora de posible vida microbiana pasada en Marte.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque muestra que Marte tuvo condiciones que podrían haber sostenido pequeños seres vivos hace mucho tiempo. Las pistas son sutiles y pequeñas, pero coinciden con lo que los científicos esperan si microbios alguna vez vivieron allí. Esto avanza la búsqueda de vida fuera de la Tierra al dar objetivos claros para estudiar.

**Próximo paso** – Para estar seguros de si la vida realmente existió, las muestras de roca deben ser traídas a la Tierra para pruebas más detalladas. Perseverance guardó estas muestras, pero la misión para devolverlas es incierta debido a posibles recortes presupuestarios. Sin traer las muestras, puede que nunca sepamos con certeza si hubo vida en Marte.

**Resumen en una frase** – El rover de la NASA encontró señales prometedoras de vida microbiana pasada en Marte, pero traer las muestras a casa es clave para confirmar este hallazgo.
